text: uh
hi everyone water purification here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new lump album
animal this is a brand new lp from the
uk music duo known as lump which
consists of singers songwriters
multi-instrumentalists laura marling and
mike lindsey of tongue fame they
christened their collaboration several
years ago with the short and sweet
self-titled lump album in 2018 at first
it was kind of peculiar seeing these two
names working so closely together on the
same project but their worlds couldn't
have fused more cohesively on this
record between the folk instrumentation
the electronics laura's voice and that
collision of sounds still exists on
animal but mike and laura have expanded
the lump universe even beyond that
putting together songs with hints of art
pop and even a bit of prog rock too
which does make the flow of this lp a
little unruly but it still was
refreshing to get another lump record
that was packed with so many sharp and
creatively layered songs for example the
wondrous opener bloom at night whose
bubbly synth arpeggios build alongside
some gorgeous horn harmonies setting the
stage for some really evocative poetry
from laura about creating finding a
claim finding fame if i'm reading this
correctly then likening that to a light
that a flower seeks out it's a pretty
thoughtful meditation that at one point
regrets this lust for light that it
speaks of now even though this
mysterious start to the record is kind
of a slow burner there are a lot of
deeper cuts here that actually kind of
rock in their own weird way the title
track for example is like a primal and
rudimentary take on a dance cut it's
very soft it's very easy going but still
incredibly danceable and there's even a
clever reference to blondie's heart of
glass in the lyrics which also plays
into
the song's main narrative reflecting on
our very organic and temporary existence
and our struggle as humans to
i guess in a way last beyond that i also
love the way that instrumentally laura
and mike kind of balance with the clunky
bass and uh the soft beats as well as
the these very stiff synth leads in one
breath it's very raw it's very natural
it's very honest sounding but then in
another it's a little stiff and
sounds like something not of this world
from here on in the track list continues
to impress climb every wall features one
of the most gorgeous and surprising
choruses on the entire lp the way the
vocals and instrumentation suddenly
slow down or break down into this
viscous wall of harmonies
this track very subtly segues into the
beautiful red snakes which
instrumentally between the pianos and
vocal there's not a whole lot to it but
the weary chords played on this track
are so heart-wrenching and laura's voice
as proven by a lot of her solo output
is just fantastic in super simple
instrumental contexts the track paradise
kind of turns up the heat with a
stronger groove these ascending synth
bass lines and a very spooky chord
progression together with laura's lyrics
about angels and ancient texts this song
feels like i'm being initiated into
a secretive space cult moving into the
last leg of the lp i think the material
begins to wane a little bit the hair on
the pillow interlude is
sparkling it's certainly pretty while
it's on but we're not really talking
about a super long record here or a
narratively difficult or complex album
either so why detour at this point in
the track list of all times i don't
really know we cannot resist though i
think is the closest this record comes
to dropping a legit rocker and yeah i
know the song overall does sound very
easy going but laura's words of kids on
the run and those kind of opaque milky
guitar lines kind of sliding all over
the mix it sounds like something thin
lizzy would play but just given this
very low-key dry folky semi-synthetic
presentation and yeah laura's words all
over the track are youthful fast
electrifying oberon i thought was an
okay track i enjoy the poetry more than
i do the song structure or the
instrumental itself which i think is
pretty scant and then we have the closer
phantom limb which
given the themes of the record up until
this point i read very much as a
meditation on the human condition
progress that still needs to be made on
it societally speaking but i will be
honest and say this was another moment
for me on the record instrumentally that
just didn't come off all that bold or as
flavorful as some of the more fusion
type tracks on the lp the song reaches a
certain point in its progression and
then like with the last uh lump lp we
have an ending where it's laura marling
dramatically reading off the credits of
the record personnel instrumentation
played studios and and i think that's a
pretty you know
quaint tradition to keep up in the midst
of this project but yeah oddly enough
even though it's been a few years down
the line and this is most definitely a
different record and it's a longer
record from lump i came away from this
thing feeling a lot of the same feelings
i did in 2018 i just kind of was left
wanting more some of the tracks felt a
little too dry a little too skeletal a
little too scant in terms of song
structure the record overall feels like
it's scratching
the surface of an idea and not getting
as deep as it possibly could i mean
granted what material it does dig out in
the process is quite good and after two
records i'm not really sure what to
attribute these consistent issues to is
this just the way that mike and lindsay
would prefer for lump to be presented is
this just their creative dynamic i don't
know still i do find their occasional
creative detours into the lump world
pretty entertaining and i hope they
continue for as often or as rare as they
may be i'm feeling a light to decent
seven on this one tran position have you
given this album a listen did you love
it did you hate it what would you rate
it you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head it's another
video that you can check out hit that up
or the link to subscribe to the channel
anthony fantano lump of forever
